nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a robust e-commerce platform that offers developers a versatile and adaptable framework to construct online stores. nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a robust e-commerce platform that offers developers a versatile and adaptable framework to construct online stores. Among its essential components, Magento 2 boasts a sophisticated layout system that permits developers to create pages and blocks with specific content and formatting. To define the structure and content of a page or block, developers employ XML files known as layout files. In this blog post, we will examine such layout files and learn how to use section.xml file in Magento 2.

What is the Section.xml file in Magento 2?

The section.xml file is responsible for defining the content and structure of sections present in a page or block. These sections act as containers for holding related content like customer data, order details, or product information, and they can have attributes like title or description.

To locate the section.xml file in a Magento 2 module, you need to navigate to the app/code/[Vendor]/[Module]/view/frontend/layout directory. In most cases, developers use this layout file in conjunction with other layout files like default.xml, catalog_product_view.xml, or page.xml to define the layout and content of a block or page.

How to use Section.xml file in Magento 2?

To use the section.xml file in Magento 2, follow these steps:

Step 1: Create the section.xml file

Create a new file called section.xml in the app/code/[Vendor]/[Module]/view/frontend/layout directory of your Magento 2 module. The file should have the following basic structure:

xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<page xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:framework:View/Layout/etc/page_configuration.xsd">

    <body>

        <!-- Define sections here -->

    </body>

</page>

Step 2: Define the sections

Inside the <body> tag, you can define one or more sections using the <referenceContainer> tag. The <referenceContainer> tag has the following attributes:

– name: The name of the container. This is used to reference the container from other layout files or templates.

 – htmlClass: The CSS class to be applied to the container.

 – htmlId: The ID to be assigned to the container.

Here is an example of a section definition:

php

<referenceContainer name="product.info.main">

    <container name="product.info.custom" htmlClass="product-info-custom" htmlId="product-info-custom" after="product.info.price">

        <argument name="title" xsi:type="string">Custom Section</argument>

        <argument name="sort_order" xsi:type="number">50</argument>

    </container>

</referenceContainer>

This example creates a new section called “product.info.custom” within the “product.info.main” container. The section has a CSS class of “product-info-custom” and an ID of “product-info-custom”. It is positioned after the “product.info.price” container. The section also has two arguments:

– title: The title of the section.

– sort_order: The order in which the section appears within its parent container.

Step 3: Use the section in a template

To display the content of a section in a template, you can use the getChildHtml() method. This method takes the name of the section container as a parameter and returns the HTML content of the section. Here is an example:

php

<div class="product-info-custom-wrapper">

    <?php echo $block->getChildHtml('product.info.custom') ?>

</div>

This example displays the content of the “product.info.custom” section within a div element with a CSS class of “product-info-custom-wrapper”.

Conclusion

The section file is an essential tool for Magento 2 developers. It allows them to define the structure and content of sections within a page or block, and customize them with specific titles, descriptions, and attributes using the <referenceContainer> tag and its attributes. These sections can be easily referenced in templates using the getChildHtml() method to display their content.

By utilizing the section.xml file in Magento 2, developers can create customized sections that display important information such as product information, customer data, or order details. They can also generate XML and HTML Sitemaps. Defining the structure and content of these sections can greatly enhance the functionality of online stores, improve website navigation, and provide a better user experience for customers.

In conclusion, the section.xml file is a valuable tool for Magento 2 developers who want to create highly customized and efficient e-commerce stores. Mastery of its use can lead to the creation of exceptional online stores that are well structured, easy to navigate, and provide a superior customer experience.

nodes.title: How to Create and Schedule Backups in Magento 2?
nodes.excerpt: As an individual who owns a store on the Magento platform, it is crucial to be equipped for unforeseen events such as data loss that may result from security breaches or system crashes. Fortunately, Magento provides an in-built tool for creating backups, which enables you to generate backups on-demand or schedule them at your convenience. … Read more
nodes.content:
As an individual who owns a store on the Magento platform, it is crucial to be equipped for unforeseen events such as data loss that may result from security breaches or system crashes. Fortunately, Magento provides an in-built tool for creating backups, which enables you to generate backups on-demand or schedule them at your convenience. In this guide on How to Create and Schedule Backups in Magento 2, we’ve covered all the essential details about Magento 2 backup, including its functioning and how to perform correct backups in Magento 2. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can ensure that your store’s data remains safe and recoverable, even in the event of a ransomware attack or other unexpected events.

How to Create and Schedule Backups in Magento 2: A Comprehensive Guide

The basics of Magento 2 backup

The Magento 2 Open Source platform is outfitted with an internal backup module that enables you to back up diverse sections of your store in two different ways. You can do this by either utilizing the admin panel or using the Magento command line interface (CLI). Furthermore, Adobe Commerce Cloud users have the added benefit of being able to utilize these two approaches as well as create a snapshot of their application environment via the Project Web Interface. This snapshot creates a comprehensive backup of all the services operating on the server, including Redis, MySQL, and Magento.

How to Create and Schedule Backups in Magento 2: As part of the backup techniques in Magento Open Source, you can generate backups of three distinct system components, namely, the file system (excluding var/ and pub/static directories), the database, and the media files kept in the pub/media directory. When you initiate the backup procedure using Magento’s integrated backup system, the platform creates a .sql file for the database and a .tgz compressed archive file for the file system and media backup files. You can locate these backup files in the var/backups directory until you decide to remove them.

How to backup Magento 2

To backup your Magento 2 data, follow these steps:

1. Activate the Magento 2 backup tool.

2. Set the value for the open files’ limit.

3. Proceed with backing up Magento 2.

4. Optionally, schedule backups for Magento 2.

5. Confirm the backup process for Magento 2.

Note – It’s worth noting that Adobe has discontinued the built-in backup feature of Magento 2 from version 2.3.0 and later. Before implementing it on a production server, ensure you test the Magento 2 backup tool in a staging environment.

Step 1:Enable the Magento 2 backup tool

  •  Log in to your Magento server as the filesystem owner and locate the project root directory.
  •  Execute the subsequent CLI command to activate the Magento backup utility:
bin/magento config: set system/backup/functionality_enabled 1

Step 2: Set the open filesâ€™ limit value

To set the open files’ limit value, follow these instructions:

1. Before initiating a backup, ensure that you update the open files’ limit value for the Magento file system user.

2. A low open file limit value can result in unsuccessful backups and rollbacks when using the Magento backup tool.

3. Adobe recommends setting the open files limit value to 65536 or higher, depending on your system capabilities.

4. To update the open files limit, execute the following command as the Magento filesystem user:

$ ulimit -s 65536

5. Confirm that the limit value has been updated by entering:

$ ulimit -n

Step 3: Backup Magento 2

To backup Magento 2, you can utilize the terminal and enter the subsequent CLI command syntax:

$ php bin/magento setup:backup [--code] [--media] [--db]

You can also select one or more options to back up specific parts of your Magento store. For example, you can back up the database and file system with the following command:

$ php bin/magento setup: backup --code --db

Alternatively, you can also back up Magento 2 using the admin panel. To do so, navigate to System > Tools > Backups and choose one of the following three options:

  •  System Backup
  •  Database and Media Backup
  •  Database Backup

On the Backup options page, input a name for your backup and select the Maintenance mode checkbox to activate maintenance mode during the backup process. After you’ve configured the backup options, click “Ok” to start the backup.

The duration of the backup process will vary depending on the size of your store, your server configuration, and the type of backup you’ve chosen. Once the backup has finished, you’ll receive a message indicating that the backup is complete.

Step 4: Schedule Magento 2 backups (optional)

If desired, you can set up a schedule to create automatic backups of your Magento 2 store on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis using the admin panel.

To do this, log in to the Magento admin panel and go to Stores > Settings > Configuration > Advanced > System.

In the Backup Settings section, make the following changes:

  •  Enable Schedule Backup: Change the value to “Yes”.
  •  Scheduled Backup Type: Select the type of backup you want to create.
  •  Start Time: Choose the time when you want the backup to be created.
  •  Frequency: Select Daily, Weekly, or Monthly as the frequency.
  •  Maintenance Mode: Change the value to “Yes”.

After making these changes, click the Save Config button to save your settings.

Step 5: Verify the Magento 2 Backup

After creating a backup in Magento 2, you can confirm its validity using either the admin panel or the terminal.

To check in the admin panel, go to System > Tools > Backups. The most recent backup will appear in the grid, where you can check its creation date, type, and size.

To check in the terminal, use the Magento CLI command:

$ php bin/magento info:backups: list

This command will list all available backups with their respective details, such as filename, creation date, and size.

How to restore a Magento 2 backup

Caution: When restoring a Magento 2 backup, all data generated by your e-commerce store after the backup was created will be permanently erased. This action cannot be reversed.

To roll back to a Magento 2 backup from the admin panel, go to System > Tools > Backups and click the Rollback link of the desired backup.

On the next page, configure the following settings:

  • User Password: Enter your Magento admin password.
  • Maintenance mode: Enable maintenance mode during the rollback by checking the box.
  • FTP (optional): Select the FTP connection option if needed.
  • Click Ok to proceed.

Alternatively, you can restore a Magento 2 backup from the command line. To do so, log in to your server as the Magento file system owner, navigate to the Magento project root, and execute the following command to display a list of available backups:


$ php bin/magento info:backups: list

The command to restore a backup may vary depending on the backup type. To restore a database backup, you can use the following command:

$ php bin/magento setup: rollback -d <backup_filename>

You can also rollback the file system backup by running the following command:

$ php bin/magento setup: rollback -c <backup_filename>

And finally, to restore the media folder backup you can use:

$ php bin/magento setup: rollback -m <backup_filename>

After executing a rollback command, Magento will prompt you to confirm if:

1. You want to proceed with the rollback.

2. You want to keep the backup file after the rollback is completed.

You can respond with “y” or “N” to both prompts, and the rollback process will complete accordingly.

In addition to creating and scheduling backups, configuring a cron job in Magento 2 is also essential for maintaining the health and performance of your store. A cron job is a scheduled task that runs automatically on your server at specific intervals. In Magento 2, the cron job can be set up via the admin panel by navigating to Stores > Configuration > Advanced > System > Cron. From there, you can configure the cron job options, such as the frequency and specific tasks to run, and ensure that the cron job is functioning correctly. By setting up a cron job, you can ensure that essential tasks, such as indexing and cache flushing, are performed regularly, improving the overall user experience of your Magento store.

Conclusion

How to Create and Schedule Backups in Magento 2: Creating and scheduling backups in Magento 2 is an essential task that helps protect your e-commerce store from data loss and downtime. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can enable the Magento backup tool, set the open files’ limit value, create and schedule backups via the CLI or admin panel, and verify and restore backups when needed. Remember to test the backup functionality in a staging environment before using it on a production server and to take caution when restoring backups, as this process is permanent and irreversible. With a solid backup strategy in place, you can have peace of mind knowing your data is safe and secure.

nodes.title: How to Configure Newsletters in Magento 2?
nodes.excerpt: Discover how to use Magento’s newsletter feature to keep your customers informed about special deals, sales, and updates in your store with this informative article titled How to Configure Newsletters in Magento 2. Email marketing can be a valuable tool for enhancing sales and building relationships with customers, and Magento simplifies newsletter management directly from … Read more
nodes.content:
Discover how to use Magento’s newsletter feature to keep your customers informed about special deals, sales, and updates in your store with this informative article titled How to Configure Newsletters in Magento 2. Email marketing can be a valuable tool for enhancing sales and building relationships with customers, and Magento simplifies newsletter management directly from the admin interface.

How to Configure Newsletters in Magento 2: A Comprehensive Guide

Step 1: to manage newsletters on your Magento store is to configure newsletter subscription options. Follow these steps:

  •  Go to Stores > Configuration > Customer > Newsletter.
  •  Enable newsletters on your store in General Options.
  •  Set “Allows Guest Subscription” to Yes, if you want unregistered users to subscribe.
  •  Choose whether the newsletter subscription needs to be confirmed by the user.
  •  Choose the confirmation email sender and template, success email sender and template, and unsubscription email sender and template.
  •  Ensure compliance with GDPR and CCPA regulations.

Once these options are set, you can proceed to the next step of adding a new newsletter template.

Step 2: After configuring newsletter subscription options is to create a newsletter template:

  •  Go to Admin Panel > Marketing > Communications > Newsletter Templates and click the “Add New Template” button.
  •  Enter a name and subject for the template.
  •  Set the sender’s name and email address.
  •  Enter the template content using the WYSIWYG editor or HTML.
  •  Design the newsletter with template styles and save the template.

Step 3: After saving the newsletter template, follow these steps to send the newsletter:

  •  Go to the Newsletter management page.
  •  Choose “Queue Newsletter” from the Action dropdown.
  •  Edit the newsletter queue by setting the Queue Date Start and saving the newsletter.
  •  Conveniently access all newsletter information on one page and make changes if needed.

Step 4: In addition to configuring, creating, and sending newsletter templates, Magento allows you to manage newsletter subscribers in two ways:

  • Go to Customers > All Customers, select the customers you want to subscribe or unsubscribe from your newsletter and choose the corresponding option from the Actions dropdown. All selected customers will be automatically subscribed or unsubscribed.
  • Go to Customers > All Customers, select the customer you want to subscribe to, go to the Newsletter section on their page, check the “Subscribed to Newsletter” option at the top of the Newsletter Information section, and save the customer.

When it comes to setting up newsletters in Magento 2, it’s important to remember that subscribing to customers without their consent is not recommended. Instead, encourage customers to sign up on their own, as it can help build a stronger relationship with them. If you subscribe to them without their knowledge, they may be confused as to why they received the newsletter and may end up unsubscribing, which could increase your bounce rates.

By following How to set up Newsletters in Magento 2 and allowing customers to opt-in on their own, you’ll be able to establish a better rapport with your audience. Ultimately, this will lead to higher engagement rates and a more successful email marketing campaign. So, take the time to set up your newsletters properly and watch your business grow.

Conclusion

In conclusion, email marketing through newsletters remains a powerful tool for building relationships and increasing sales. With Magento 2, managing newsletters and subscribers is made easy directly from the admin panel. By following the four steps outlined above, including how to use a custom price template in Magento 2, you can configure your newsletter settings, create newsletter templates, send newsletters, and manage subscribers. Remember, it is important to allow customers to subscribe to your newsletter willingly to avoid an increase in bounce rates. Are you looking to establish a stronger connection with your customers and keep them updated on special offers, sales, and store updates? Look no further than Magento 2’s newsletter feature! With proper configuration, you can utilize this powerful tool to its fullest potential. Learn how to configure newsletters in Magento 2 and take advantage of this great feature today.

nodes.title: How To Configure Magento 2 Add Extra Fee In Checkout
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a popular eCommerce platform that offers various features to its users, including the ability to add an extra fee to the checkout process. This can be useful for businesses that want to charge additional fees for specific products or services. In this article, we will explain how to configure Magento 2 to … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a popular eCommerce platform that offers various features to its users, including the ability to add an extra fee to the checkout process. This can be useful for businesses that want to charge additional fees for specific products or services. In this article, we will explain how to configure Magento 2 to add extra fee in checkout process. Additionally, we will provide an overview of how the checkout process is organized in Magento 2. So, whether you’re looking to add extra fees to your checkout process or simply want to understand how it works, this article has got you covered.

How To Configure Magento 2 Add Extra Fee In Checkout: A Step-by-Step Guide

Why do you need to add an extra fee?

Store owners who provide additional services, such as one-day delivery, gift wrapping, or extended warranty, may find adding extra charges to their store extremely useful. However, the default Magento platform only supports a limited number of fees, such as free shipping, table rate, or flat rate, which can be problematic. When an additional fee is incurred, store owners often have to add it directly to product prices, which can result in two issues. The Magento 2 add extra fee in checkout feature can assist e-commerce store owners in solving the problem of customers being unaware of added fees, which may lead to abandoned shopping carts due to increased product prices. This function allows for the addition of extra charges during the checkout process, providing customers with a clear understanding of the associated costs. Moreover, fees can be displayed on the storefront, enabling shoppers to conveniently view the charges when they add items to their shopping cart. By utilizing this feature, store owners can improve their customer’s shopping experience while avoiding cart abandonment issues.

Configure Magento 2 to add an extra fee in checkout programmatically.

For those who are well-versed in coding and prefer a no-cost option, configuring Magento 2 Add Extra Fee in Checkout programmatically is a viable solution. The first step is to create a sales.xml file in your module’s etc. folder.

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<config xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:module:Magento_Sales:etc/sales.xsd">
    <section name="quote">
        <group name="totals">
            <item name="customfee" instance="Webguru\Test\Model\Total\Customfee" sort_order="150"/>
        </group>  
    </section>
</config>

Now, define app\code\Webguru\Test\Model\Total\Customfee.php.

At this stage, you can activate the feature to update your total based on your custom fee.

class Customfee extends \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote\Address\Total\AbstractTotal
{
   /**
     * Collect grand total address amount
     *
     * @param \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote $quote
     * @param \Magento\Quote\Api\Data\ShippingAssignmentInterface $shippingAssignment
     * @param \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote\Address\Total $total
     * @return $this
     */
    protected $quoteValidator = null; 

    public function __construct(\Magento\Quote\Model\QuoteValidator $quoteValidator)
    {
        $this->quoteValidator = $quoteValidator;
    }
  public function collect(
        \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote $quote,        \Magento\Quote\Api\Data\ShippingAssignmentInterface $shippingAssignment,
        \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote\Address\Total $total
    ) {
        parent::collect($quote, $shippingAssignment, $total);


        $exist_amount = 0; //$quote->getCustomfee(); 
        $customfee = 100; //enter amount which you want to set
        $balance = $customfee - $exist_amount;//final amount

        $total->setTotalAmount('customfee', $balance);
        $total->setBaseTotalAmount('customfee', $balance);

        $total->setCustomfee($balance);
        $total->setBaseCustomfee($balance);

        $total->setGrandTotal($total->getGrandTotal() + $balance);
        $total->setBaseGrandTotal($total->getBaseGrandTotal() + $balance);


        return $this;
    } 

    protected function clearValues(Address\Total $total)
    {
        $total->setTotalAmount('subtotal', 0);
        $total->setBaseTotalAmount('subtotal', 0);
        $total->setTotalAmount('tax', 0);
        $total->setBaseTotalAmount('tax', 0);
        $total->setTotalAmount('discount_tax_compensation', 0);
        $total->setBaseTotalAmount('discount_tax_compensation', 0);
        $total->setTotalAmount('shipping_discount_tax_compensation', 0);
        $total->setBaseTotalAmount('shipping_discount_tax_compensation', 0);
        $total->setSubtotalInclTax(0);
        $total->setBaseSubtotalInclTax(0);
    }
    /**
     * @param \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote $quote
     * @param Address\Total $total
     * @return array|null
     */
    /**
     * Assign subtotal amount and label to address object
     *
     * @param \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote $quote
     * @param Address\Total $total
     * @return array
     */
    public function fetch(\Magento\Quote\Model\Quote $quote, \Magento\Quote\Model\Quote\Address\Total $total)
    {
        return [
            'code' => 'custom fee',
            'title' => 'Custom Fee',
            'value' => 100
        ];
    }

    /**
     * Get Subtotal label
     *
     * @return \Magento\Framework\Phrase
     */
    public function getLabel()
    {
        return __('Custom Fee');
    }
}

Here’s a possible rephrased version of the text.

And that’s all there is to it. By following just two steps, you can add a customs fee to your checkout page.

Conclusion

Online businesses may find it beneficial to include extra fees during the checkout process to provide additional services or cover costs. While Magento 2 has pre-built fee options, the platform’s Add Extra Fee in Checkout feature allows for a more personalized approach. By following the guidelines provided in this article on how to configure Magento 2 to add extra fee in checkout, store owners can easily set up this feature to meet their specific needs and enhance their customers’ shopping experience. Magento 2’s flexibility and functionality make it an excellent option for eCommerce businesses of all sizes looking to configure Magento 2 Add Extra Fee in Checkout. Overall, this feature can be a valuable addition for online businesses seeking to provide transparency and clarity to their customers during the checkout process.

nodes.content:
For a solution on How To Remove Billing And Shipping Address From Magento 2 Checkout, the Baymard Institute reports that cart abandonment rates are nearly 70%, with 26% due to checkout issues. However, store owners can increase conversions by 35.62% through checkout optimization. To succeed in the competitive eCommerce market, store owners should prioritize optimizing the customer experience, which includes customizing the billing and shipping address section of the checkout process. Check out this article for a solution to this problem.

How to Remove Billing and Shipping Address from Magento 2 Checkout – A Guide

In Magento 2 Checkout by Default: Billing and Shipping Address

Magento’s default checkout process consists of 3 sections: Billing & Shipping Address, Shipping Methods, and Payment Method, all of which are essential for a seamless shopping and selling experience.

In Magento 2, the Payment Method section typically displays the Billing Address, but it is only shown if the customer does not select the ‘My billing and shipping address are the same’ option. However, some store owners may want to customize the checkout process by relocating the Billing Address to the Shipping section and removing the Billing and Shipping Address checkboxes. If you are seeking guidance on how to accomplish this modification, we provide step-by-step instructions below on how to Remove Billing and shipping address from Checkout Magento 2.

Remove Billing and Shipping Address From Check out Magento 2

Use the following code:

/* config: checkout/options/display_billing_address_on = payment_method */
            if (isset($jsLayoutResult['components']['checkout']['children']['steps']['children']['billing-step']['children']
                ['payment']['children']['payments-list']['children']
            )) {
                foreach ($jsLayoutResult['components']['checkout']['children']['steps']['children']['billing-step']['children']
                         ['payment']['children']['payments-list']['children'] as $key => $payment) {

                    unset($jsLayoutResult['components']['checkout']['children']['steps']['children']['billing-step']['children']
                        ['payment']['children']['payments-list']['children'][$key]);

                }
            }

After following the steps, the Billing Address will no longer appear in the Payment Method section.

Note – that if any websites utilize checkout agreements, they will also be removed. To retain the checkout agreement on the checkout page, the admin must add the following code to the agreements block.

if (isset($jsLayoutResult['components']['checkout']['children']['steps']['children']['billing-step']['children']['payment']['children']['payments-list']['children']
)) {
    foreach ($jsLayoutResult['components']['checkout']['children']['steps']['children']['billing-step']['children']['payment']['children']['payments-list']['children'] as $key => $payment) {

                if($key == 'before-place-order') {
                    foreach ($jsLayoutResult['components']['checkout']['children']['steps']['children']['billing-step']['children']['payment']['children']['payments-list']['children']['before-place-order']['children'] as $key => $payment) {
                        if($key == 'agreements') {
                            continue;
                        }
                    }
                }
                unset($jsLayoutResult['components']['checkout']['children']['steps']['children']['billing-step']['children']
                    ['payment']['children']['payments-list']['children'][$key]);
    }
}

By default, Magento sets up the checkout process in three sections, including Billing & Shipping Address, Shipping Methods, and Payment Method. All three sections are important to complete the shopping and selling experience.

Conclusion

we have discussed how the checkout process is organized in Magento 2 and how you can modify it to better suit your needs. In Magento 2, the checkout process is divided into three sections: Billing & Shipping Address, Shipping Methods, and Payment Method. However, store owners may prefer to streamline the process and eliminate the billing and shipping address section. To accomplish this, you can follow the steps outlined in this article on How To Remove Billing And Shipping Address From Magento 2 Checkout. Understanding the structure of the checkout process in Magento 2 is crucial for store owners who wish to optimize their customers’ shopping experience. Additionally, if you want to specifically remove the shipping address section, you can search for Magento 2 remove shipping address from checkout.

nodes.content:
Many e-commerce stores face challenges in dealing with customers from different countries who use different currencies. However, there is a solution available in Magento 2 that allows you to change the global price scope. This is essential since various factors can impact product prices. In this article, we will provide you with a step-by-step guide on How To Change Magento 2 Price Scope & Overcome Default Configuration.

How to Optimize Pricing in Magento 2: A Comprehensive Overview

Overview of Magento price Scope Default Configuration

Magento 2 offers two options for configuring prices for store catalogs: global and website level, both of which use the base currency scope. With the “Global” option selected under “Catalog Price Scope,” the same price is applied throughout the entire store. On the other hand, the “Website” option allows for different pricing strategies on each website level. However, since Magento 2 sets the default configuration to “Global,” prices remain the same across all store views, creating difficulties in providing varied rates for specific locations or markets. If you want to overcome this default configuration, you can learn how to change Magento 2 price scope by following the steps in this tutorial on How To Change Magento 2 Price Scope & Overcome Default Configuration.

Who & Why Needs to Configure Magento 2 Price Scope

What if you could change the price scope in Magento 2 to store view? To determine if you need multiple store view pricing, consider if you sell to different customer groups simultaneously with varying prices for each product. Displaying multiple prices based on store views makes it easy to manage and track, and expands your customer base. If you have B2B and B2C catalogs, it’s necessary to distinguish prices. Changing the Magento 2 price scope to store view can adapt to your demands and adjust fair pricing for particular local customers. This also automatically adjusts operations and delivery for each location. Using multiple-store view pricing can boost your company’s competitiveness by offering lower prices in a crowded market or raising prices for high-demand products. Learn more about what is Store View in Magento 2 and how it can benefit your business.

How to Change Magento 2 Price Scope Without Coding Knowledge [Website & StoreView]

CHANGE PRICE SCOPE VIA MAGENTO 2 BACKEND

Changing the Magento 2 price scope via the backend is simple and can be done in three steps. 

Step 1: Choose “Stores” on the dashboard and then “Configuration.” 

Step 2: click on the “Catalog” section and select “Catalog.” 

Step 3: scroll down to the “Price” section and choose either “Global” or “Website.” Don’t forget to save the configuration.

Overcome Default Configuration With Magento 2 Multiple-Store View Pricing

With the Magento 2 Multiple Store View Pricing extension, store administrators can easily configure Magento 2 price scope by setting up the base currency for each store view. This extension enables you to establish different prices for the same product on each view, as it adjusts the price scope to the store view level. This allows for product pricing, special pricing, or tier pricing to differ based on the store view. When customers check out, they can use the base currency of the store view, which follows the default settings of Magento where they typically purchase using the website’s base currency. Moreover, this module facilitates the selection of the base currency for each store view, making it easy for you to configure Magento 2 price scope.

Conclusion

If you’re looking to modify the price scope in Magento 2, it’s essential to have a good understanding of three key concepts: catalog price scope, base currency, and default display currency. While you can set the default display currency based on store views, the catalog price scope and base currency can only be changed following the Global/Website options set by default in Magento. However, there is a solution to this limitation in the form of the Magento 2 Multiple Store View Pricing modules. This module offers pricing flexibility, which can improve business efficiency and reduce costs associated with the selling process. Additionally, it can save customers time and effort by encouraging them to complete transactions more quickly with the store’s currency. As a result, this module can create a win-win situation for both you and your customers. So, if you’re wondering how to change Magento 2 price scope and overcome default configuration, the Multiple Store View Pricing modules are a great solution to consider.

nodes.content:
Nowadays, there are numerous mobile devices available in the market with varying brands, models, and operating systems. It can be quite tedious to test each one of them individually. If you want to enhance the mobile-friendliness of your Magento 2 website, ensure the responsiveness of your Magento store, or test custom options and modules, you have come to the right place. This article will provide you with insights on How to Test Magento 2 Extensions on Mobile Devices. We will help you select the appropriate mobile devices for testing and also highlight the essential tests that you need to perform to ensure the seamless functioning of your Magento 2 extensions on mobile devices.

A Comprehensive Guide for Test Magento 2 Extensions on Mobile Devices

Mobile device selection criteria

Testing Magento 2 extensions on mobile devices is crucial for ensuring that your website provides a seamless user experience for mobile users. One example of this is the Free Shipping Bar module, which allows you to add a banner to multiple pages of your Magento 2 store and customize its design in the admin panel. To ensure that the banner is positioned correctly, the text fits within the borders, and it functions seamlessly on mobile devices, it’s important to test these customizations using the guidelines outlined in How to Test Magento 2 Extensions on Mobile Devices. This involves creating a device weighting table to identify relevant devices, using a range of testing tools such as browser emulators and mobile device emulators, and testing on different screen sizes, resolutions, and operating systems. By testing thoroughly on mobile devices, you can avoid any issues that could negatively impact your website’s performance and provide a positive user experience for your mobile users.

Analyze the popularity of mobile device statistics

The next step is to analyze the most in-demand devices in the countries you’ve identified. This will streamline the list of necessary devices for testing, leading to the elimination of some devices and prioritizing others.

There are numerous resources available for obtaining information on device popularity across different countries. Some of these include:

  •  appbrain.com, which provides statistics on Android device popularity worldwide
  •  deviceatlas.com, which offers information on the top 12 devices in various countries, including both iOS and Android devices
  •  gs.statcounter.com, which allows you to track the distribution of manufacturers across different countries over time, and provides customizable graphs based on your needs
  •  mixpanel.com, which provides statistics on Apple devices, including data on specific versions of iOS compared to previous versions and market trends for different iPhone models.

Check the prevalence of OS

Finally, consider the popularity of different operating system versions. By this point, you should already have a preliminary list of devices, which can be used to determine the most relevant operating systems. Some operating systems may even be excluded from consideration.

To determine the necessary operating systems, consider the following sources:

  •  developer.android.com, the official Google site that lists detailed versions of Android
  •  developer.apple.com, the official Apple site that displays currently popular versions of iOS
  •  appbrain.com, a service that allows you to evaluate the popularity of Android operating systems
  •  David-smith.org, a site that provides the distribution of older iOS versions by the device.

Points to remember

Having a comprehensive understanding of the market you operate in is crucial. It’s important to use the latest statistics, as data that’s more than a year old may not be applicable anymore, especially when it comes to mobile devices and operating systems. Steer clear of complicated lists that rank the most expensive, powerful, and popular devices, as these might not be relevant to your target market. For instance, the Samsung S10 may be a widely known and robust smartphone, but it may not be well-liked by users in India.

Note – if you want to install an extension in Magento 2 manually, you can follow our guidelines on How to Install an Extension in Magento 2 Manually.

Testing on mobile devices

It’s imperative to test your Magento 2 extension on mobile devices if you have made any modifications or additions to the front end or admin panel. This is to ensure that the new elements match the declared layout and display correctly on various devices.

For instance, our One Step Checkout module provides customization options such as the number of columns and the placement of the Place Order button. Hence, it’s crucial to test how these customizations appear on mobile devices to ensure that everything is displayed correctly and functions as intended.

Testing Magento 2 extensions on mobile devices is crucial for ensuring that your website is accessible and user-friendly for mobile users. One example of an extension that requires testing on mobile devices is the Free Shipping Bar module. This module allows you to add a banner to multiple pages of your Magento 2 store and customize its design in the admin panel. To ensure that the banner is positioned correctly, the text fits within the borders, and it functions seamlessly on mobile devices, it’s important to perform Magento 2 extension checks on mobile devices. By using mobile device emulators or physical devices, you can test the extension’s functionality and design on a range of devices with different screen sizes and resolutions. Testing the Free Shipping Bar module on mobile devices using the techniques described in Magento 2 Extension check on mobile Devices will help you provide a seamless user experience and avoid any issues that could negatively impact your business.

In every new extension, make sure to thoroughly check the display of all elements on mobile devices. Here is a list of basic checks to perform:

  •  Check the overall appearance and design.
  •  Test the functionality of each element in all states.
  •  Ensure all elements are clickable and their behavior is as expected.
  •  Check for compatibility with popular Magento 2 mobile themes.
  •  Verify that elements do not overlap.
  •  Test the scalability of an element.
  •  Check the functionality of links.
  •  Verify the proper functioning of any validation forms.
  •  Compare the display of elements in different browsers.
  •  Check if the letters match the declared design if the module has this feature.

Remember to also test any functionality that was specifically designed for mobile devices, such as our Magento 2 Stripe Payment. It is recommended to optimize your payment methods for mobile devices to meet new security requirements.

To Conclude

If you want to optimize your Magento website for mobile devices, it’s important to follow specific guidelines for testing Magento 2 extensions on mobile devices. By doing so, you can ensure that your website is accessible and user-friendly for mobile users.

One of the key steps in testing Magento 2 extensions on mobile devices is to create a device weighting table to identify the most important devices for your business requirements. This will help you prioritize your testing efforts and focus on the devices that matter the most.

Once you have identified the relevant devices, you can use a range of tools to test your extensions, such as browser emulators, mobile device emulators, or physical devices. It’s crucial to test your extensions on a variety of devices to ensure that they work correctly on different screen sizes and resolutions.

Additionally, you should consider testing your extensions on different operating systems and browser types to ensure compatibility with a wide range of mobile devices. By testing thoroughly using the right tools and techniques, you can provide a seamless user experience and avoid any issues that could negatively impact your business.

In conclusion, testing Magento 2 extensions on mobile devices is a crucial step in optimizing your website for mobile users. By following the guidelines and using the right tools, such as the ones described in How to Test Magento 2 Extensions on Mobile Devices, you can collect valuable data and make informed decisions to improve your website’s performance on mobile devices.

nodes.title: How to Pre-Launch Website Checklist in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Launching a new website can be an important milestone for a business, providing a chance to showcase products or services to a broader audience. However, it can also be a stressful time, given the impact a website launch can have on brand reputation and sales. Therefore, it’s essential to ensure that everything is in order … Read more
nodes.content:
Launching a new website can be an important milestone for a business, providing a chance to showcase products or services to a broader audience. However, it can also be a stressful time, given the impact a website launch can have on brand reputation and sales. Therefore, it’s essential to ensure that everything is in order before going live.

A pre-launch website checklist is designed to ensure website readiness by addressing crucial areas such as website design and layout, website functionality, content, and performance. These include checking for visual appeal and alignment with brand identity, fast page loading speeds, optimized SEO, and streamlined checkout processes.

This blog post will explore how to pre-launch website checklist in Magento 2, covering essential tasks like setting up a staging environment to test the website, configuring payment and shipping options, optimizing website performance, and testing website functionality.

Essentials to Create a Pre-Launch Website Checklist in Magento 2

1. Test the Website’s Performance

    It’s essential to test your website’s performance to ensure that it can handle the expected traffic. Use tools like Google PageSpeed Insights or GTmetrix to analyze your website’s load time, page speed, and performance. Make sure that your website’s images are optimized and that the website has been cached.

2. Check the Website’s Responsiveness

    Test your website’s responsiveness by using different devices and screen sizes to ensure that it looks good and functions well on all devices. Responsive design is essential for providing a seamless user experience and improving the website’s search engine optimization (SEO).

3. Check the Website’s Security

    Ensure that your website is secure by installing an SSL certificate, configuring your website’s security settings, and testing your website for vulnerabilities. Use tools like MageReport or OWASP ZAP to scan your website for security vulnerabilities.

4. Check the Website’s Content

    Ensure that your website’s content is complete, accurate, and optimized for search engines. Review all pages, including the homepage, product pages, category pages, and about us page, to make sure that the content is consistent, engaging, and free of errors.

5. Check the Website’s Checkout Process

    Test your website’s checkout process by creating a test order to ensure that it’s easy to use, secure, and functioning correctly. Make sure that all payment methods and shipping options are working correctly and that customers can complete their orders without any issues.

6. Set up Analytics and Tracking

In addition to the tasks mentioned above, it’s also important to add Google Analytics data in Magneto 2. Installing and configuring analytics and tracking tools, such as Google Analytics, is crucial to monitor your website’s performance, track user behavior, and measure the success of your marketing campaigns. This data can help you make data-driven decisions and improve your website’s user experience and performance. With Google Analytics integration in Magneto 2, you can easily track important metrics such as pageviews, bounce rates, and conversion rates, and use this data to optimize your website for better results. Therefore, make sure to add Google Analytics to your pre-launch website checklist for Magento 2.

7. Create a Backup and Disaster Recovery Plan

    Ensure that your website’s data is backed up and that you have a disaster recovery plan in place in case of an unexpected outage or data loss. Use tools like Magento Backup or Magento Cloud to create regular backups of your website’s data.

Conclusion

Crafting a pre-launch website checklist in Magento 2 is crucial to ensuring that your website is fully prepared for launch and capable of providing an exceptional user experience. By conducting performance tests, assessing website responsiveness and security, evaluating content, reviewing the checkout process, and analyzing website analytics, you can detect and resolve any issues before they impact your website’s users. Furthermore, implementing a backup and disaster recovery plan can safeguard your website’s data and reduce the impact of any unforeseen problems. By adhering to this pre-launch website checklist, you can launch a prosperous and lucrative Magento 2 website.

nodes.title: How to Configure Content Delivery Network (CDN) in Magento 2 store
nodes.excerpt: Since its inception in 2007, Magento has established itself as a significant player in the e-commerce industry. With the launch of Magento 2, the platform has undergone numerous improvements that make it even easier to launch an online store. These improvements include scalable architecture, the latest frameworks, and more user-friendly coding patterns. There is no … Read more
nodes.content:
Since its inception in 2007, Magento has established itself as a significant player in the e-commerce industry. With the launch of Magento 2, the platform has undergone numerous improvements that make it even easier to launch an online store. These improvements include scalable architecture, the latest frameworks, and more user-friendly coding patterns.

There is no question that Magento 2 is the preferred choice for powering online businesses. This is reflected in its 26% market share and projections to generate $4.14 trillion in sales by 2020.

From small businesses to big-name brands like Nike, Christian Louboutin, and Vizio, many of the world’s leading e-commerce sites rely on Magento, utilizing a Content Delivery Network (CDN) for optimal performance.

How do you configure a content delivery network (CDN) in the Magento 2 store?

A CDN accelerates content delivery for high-traffic websites and online stores with a global presence and protects against sudden spikes in traffic. Additionally, it makes the website faster for customers worldwide, leading to an improved user experience.

To improve the performance of your Magento 2 website, especially when it comes to handling a large amount of data such as HD videos, flash sales, and large downloads, it’s crucial to utilize a Content Delivery Network (CDN). By implementing a CDN, you can ensure that your e-commerce site is capable of handling high traffic demands with lightning-fast speed, which is essential for meeting customer expectations of a seamless and speedy experience.

If your Magento 2 store can’t deliver the performance that customers expect, they will likely look for alternative options. Therefore, it’s important to understand how to use CDN in Magento 2 effectively, as it can significantly impact the overall user experience and increase customer satisfaction.

Streamlining Magento 2 with CDN: A Comprehensive Walkthrough

What Is a CDN And Why E-commerce Sites Need One?

How to speed up Magento 2 is a crucial aspect to consider for online success, as customers expect quick website loading and a seamless experience. The speed of a Magento 2 store is largely determined by the hosting provider and the location of its data center. For example, hosting with a provider like GoDaddy or SiteGround in a North American data center will result in faster load times for users in the same region. However, those visiting the site from further away, such as in Asia, may experience slower performance.

One effective way to speed up Magento 2 is by utilizing a Content Delivery Network (CDN). CDNs improve the delivery of content and data, enhancing the overall user experience for Magento 2 e-commerce stores, eliminating slow load times, and ensuring seamless performance for all visitors, regardless of their location.

How CDN works?

Setting up a Content Delivery Network (CDN) is an essential step for enhancing the performance of a Magento 2 store. A CDN operates by utilizing a network of servers placed strategically across the globe, which hold a cached version of the website’s content. This network of servers collaborates to transfer important assets such as product images, CSS and JavaScript files, videos, and more, ensuring faster load times and seamless operations.

By hosting the cached content on a CDN, data is transmitted at lightning-fast speeds, reducing page load times considerably. But the benefits of CDNs extend far beyond quick page loading times. With the right configuration, a CDN can also attract traffic from multiple platforms like YouTube and Facebook, and protect against spam and malicious attacks.

In conclusion, CDNs play an instrumental role in enhancing the customer experience for online businesses and merchants. Knowing how to set up a Content Delivery Network (CDN) in a Magento 2 store is crucial for maximizing the potential of your online business and keeping your customers happy.

Advantages of CDNs for Magento 2 Merchants

utilizing Magento 2, you can create a feature-rich website that effectively displays all of your products and provides customers with a seamless checkout process. However, a high-quality CDN can further enhance your website’s capabilities by making it faster and more secure for visitors.

Here’s how a CDN can benefit your Magento 2 website:

Reduced Bandwidth and Infrastructure Costs:

For e-commerce websites, information must flow smoothly between servers, connecting sellers and buyers seamlessly. However, when there is a heavy influx of traffic, it can consume bandwidth and hinder the flow of information. To overcome this challenge, a Content Delivery Network (CDN) can help reduce the strain on bandwidth by regulating data flow while simultaneously fulfilling data requests from visitors. This is particularly advantageous for Magento 2, as it provides a superior infrastructure and dynamic capacity, ultimately enhancing the overall user experience.

Improved Content Delivery:

In the world of e-commerce, delivering content quickly and seamlessly is essential for business success. Fortunately, Magento 2 has made significant performance improvements compared to previous versions. However, the use of a Content Delivery Network (CDN) can take this a step further by ensuring swift delivery and seamless display of content. With a CDN, e-commerce businesses can achieve exceptional performance and provide a superior user experience for their customers.

Increased Website Security:

Magento 2 provides advanced security features, such as two-factor authentication and SSL, to safeguard your online store. Nevertheless, even the most secure servers may still be exposed to viruses and malicious content. In such cases, a Content Delivery Network (CDN) can help fortify the security of your data and information by securing it with powerful TLS/SSL certification. By using a CDN, e-commerce businesses can add an extra layer of protection to their store, ensuring the safety of their customer’s sensitive data and enhancing their overall trust in the brand.

Enhanced Web Analytics:

Reporting and analytics are crucial for a successful and profitable online presence. Magento 2 provides insights into orders, customers, and products, but a CDN can deliver even better web analytics, including page loading time, visitor engagement, and overall website performance. Combined with Google Analytics, these statistics can help you improve the customer experience and carry out target market analysis.

Scalability and Flexibility:

Magento 2 makes it easy for administrators to create and edit product information without causing data conflicts, and a CDN can further empower the platform by keeping costs low and improving efficiency and security.

Lower Bounce Rate:

In the online world, faster-loading websites tend to attract higher engagement and sales, as Google considers site speed as a ranking factor and visitors generally prefer sites that load quickly. A high bounce rate can indicate that visitors are quickly leaving your site, and page load time can significantly affect this metric. Integrating a Content Delivery Network (CDN) with your Magento 2 website can greatly improve its loading speed, resulting in a lower bounce rate and higher visitor engagement. With a CDN, e-commerce businesses can deliver a fast and seamless user experience, which can lead to higher conversion rates and greater business success.

Higher Search Engine Rankings:

High bounce rates can lower your website’s ranking in search results, and slow page loading times can also negatively impact your ranking. A fast-loading site with a low bounce rate will have a higher chance of ranking well in search results, even if other factors such as content, navigation, and advertisements are equal between the two sites.

Steps to Configure a Content Delivery Network in Magento 2

Here are the steps you need to follow to configure a Content Delivery Network (CDN) in your Magento 2 store:

  1. Go to the Admin panel and click on “Stores”. Then, select “Configuration” in the Settings section.
  2. In the panel on the left, select “Web” under “General”.
  3. Open the “Base URLs” section and follow these instructions:
  • In the “Base URL for Static View Files” field, enter the URL of the location on the CDN where static view files are stored.
  • In the “Base URL for User Media Files” field, enter the URL of the JavaScript files on the CDN.

Once you have completed the above steps, click on “Save Config”. Note that all of the fields mentioned above can be left blank, or they can start with the placeholder “{{unsecure_base_url}}”.

Final Thoughts

If you’re looking to improve the performance and scalability of your Magento 2 store, you can do so by configuring a Content Delivery Network (CDN). Learning How to Configure a Content Delivery Network (CDN) in a Magento 2 store is a great way to offer a superior shopping experience to your customers while benefiting from enhanced testing capabilities and increased scalability.

To get started with configuring a CDN in your Magento 2 store, you’ll first need to select a compatible CDN provider. Once you’ve chosen a provider, you’ll need to configure the CDN settings in your Magento 2 store by specifying the CDN domain name and setting up caching rules that are appropriate for your specific needs.

After configuring your CDN in the Magento 2 store, it’s essential to test it to ensure that it’s functioning properly and delivering the expected performance improvements. By properly configuring your CDN in the Magento 2 store, you’ll be able to offer your customers faster page load times, a more reliable shopping experience, and ultimately increase customer satisfaction and conversions.

nodes.content:
Magento 2 is an e-commerce platform renowned for its versatility and robustness, offering users an array of features and functionalities. Pricing is a vital element of any online store, and Magento 2 provides an all-encompassing pricing system that empowers store owners to regulate their product prices, considering factors like customer groups, websites, and currencies.

The price scope is a crucial configuration setting within Magento 2’s pricing system. In this blog post, we will explore the process of how to configure Magento 2 price scope.

What is the Price Scope in Magento 2?

Price scope in Magento 2 determines the level at which prices are defined and managed. Magento 2 offers two price scopes:

Global scope: Prices are set globally and apply to all websites and stores within a Magento instance.

Website scope: Prices are set at the website level, which means that prices can differ between different websites within a Magento instance.

When creating a new store in Magento 2, you have the option to choose the price scope. You can also change the price scope later from the Magento admin panel.

How to Configure Price Scope in Magento 2

Configuring the price scope in Magento 2 involves a few simple steps. Let’s take a look at them:

Step 1: Log in to the Magento Admin Panel

Log in to your Magento 2 admin panel using your credentials.

Step 2: Navigate to Stores > Settings > Configuration

In the admin panel, navigate to Stores > Settings > Configuration.

Step 3: Select Catalog from the left-hand menu

In the Configuration page, select the Catalog option from the left-hand menu.

Step 4: Expand the Price section

In the Catalog section, expand the Price section by clicking on it.

Step 5: Choose the Price Scope

Under the Price section, you will find the Price Scope option. You can choose either the Global or Website scope from the dropdown menu.

Step 6: Save the Configuration

After selecting the Price Scope, click on the Save Config button to save the changes.

Congratulations! You have successfully configured the price scope in Magento 2.

Conclusion

Setting up the price scope correctly in Magento 2 is a vital component of managing your product pricing effectively. With the right price scope and use custom price templates, you can establish prices that are tailored and accurate to your customers’ needs, resulting in an improved shopping experience.

It’s essential to bear in mind that once you’ve set the price scope, changing it to the other scope necessitates resetting your store completely. Therefore, it’s imperative to select the right price scope for your store at the outset.

We trust that this blog has given you valuable insights into configuring the price scope in Magento 2. If you have any queries or feedback, please don’t hesitate to leave a comment below.
